comment._content: Bunmahon/Bonmahon was a copper mining area. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunmahon Old OSI map shows lots of disused mines. No idea where this new mine could be. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,642741,598456,7,9 The men are standing on the rickety headstocks, probably salvaged from another mine. One of a pair of winding wheels is lying in the foreground. There is a substantial winding house on the right, with a temporary steam sinking winch. Once the shaft sinkers had got down to the copper seams, more substantial headstocks would be built over the shaft. Here are some coal mine sinkers www.flickr.com/photos/53560486@N04/6221476026/

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/14302637@N08] knows a lot more about mining than I do and thank you for the information, it makes sense of the shot.  Another example of a health and safety nightmare today but the norm in those days.  Theres an awful lot of people standing on a flimsy looking frame.  It looks as though this was a new mine about to be opened or an old mine about to be closed.  I suspect the former given the condition of the piping on the right foreground.  I was looking at the frame and wondering if it could withstand the pull from winch but if you look closely you can see the supports on that side are angled out to brace it against the pull of the winch!  Lord how things have changed in 100 years!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The Times (London) of Nov 25 1905 reported a speculative venture to reopen mines at Bunmahon . Could the picture be showing one of these mines in the process of being reopened? The Bonmahon Copper Mines Development Syndicate (Limited) has a capital of £30,000 in £1 shares, of which 12,500 shares are reserved for working capital, and subscriptions are invited for the balance. The company is formed to acquire the mineral and mining rights, free from all royalties and charges, of the Knockmahon and Tankardstown Copper Mines, to reopen the mines, and afterwards (if deemed advisable) to form a larger company to work and develop the property on an adequate scale. The purchase consideration to be paid for the property is £16,250, of which £5,000 is payable in cash and the balance in shares. The venture is frankly speculative, but it is interesting from the point of view of the possible revival of a once important Irish industry, and the present position of the copper market is in its favour. A short youtube clip about one of the Bunmahon mines here.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The venture to reopen the mines seems not to have been a success - the company was wound up in 1907, and the investors, many from the Waterford area, lost their money. There seem to have been big problems removing water from the mines. TheTankardstown mine went a considerable distance under the sea.

In 1910 the man behind the attempted reopening, a Mr Herbert Tristman Marks, was criticised in a magazine article, which suggested the prospectus had misled investors. He sued the magazine, lost the case, then lost an appeal, and was then declared bankrupt.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Very interesting video. Shaft sinkers were a breed apart. They went up and down shafts in a large bucket until their work was finished. Only then were cages fitted for hauling coal or man-riding. The Hartley Colliery disaster of 1862 brought legislation so that there were 2 shafts to give miners an escape route. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartley_Colliery_Disaster Non-ferrous mines (lead, tin, copper) seemed to be less regulated than coal mines. What is the difference between a well and a mine? With a well you dig a shaft to look for water.

comment._content: No, the sinkers have yet to arrive. The men in the photo have built the headstocks and cleared a bit of land where the shaft will be sunk, hence the small pile of rubble on the left. A sinker wore a caped hat to prevent water cascading down the back of the neck. These rescuers were similar brave men who went down the shaft in a big bucket when the cage was wrecked. www.flickr.com/photos/beamishmuseum/4837446319/ Women were employed on the surface to sort out stones from the coal or ore-bearing rock. The women and girls were employed on the surface, screening stone from the coal. Old men were also put on to this work. Here is one of my ancestors. "DEATH of a Peter DOCHERTY, 24 Sept 1868 aged 60 years. The death certificate:- "a screener at a coal pit" His head was crushed by waggons at screens at Usworth Pit. comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 56 men including a few youngfellas...!!! approx weight 4.5 to 5 tons. I believe this to be the location.Streetview--in the townland of Knockmahon. The photograph was taken looking down from near where the horse box is in the Google view. The site of the shaft in relation to the building matches the positions shown on the 25"OSI.. Also, to the right of the horse box the remains of three metal corner posts presumably surrounding the old shaft can clearly be seen in the Google view. While the stone walls are not shown on the 25"ordinance map the remains of the lower one in the photograph can be seen in the Google view and on the OSI street map(Beta). What [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] has 'noted' as a "pit heap" is the slated roof of the building next to the 'engine house' as seen on the 25"map. Its too neat to be mine tailings.Such neat heaps can only be achieved when the material is dropped from a height.. ie .conveyor. There is also a long dark horizontal stone half way up the far side of the upper sash that matches a stone in the Google view, albeit a bit fuzzy. The composition of this photograph is brilliant. And not forgetting a horse. a mare maybe.... ?
